text:
Singapore: Inside Out Brings Singapore’s Creative Talents to New York City  
Singapore: Inside Out, an international travelling showcase featuring works by some of Singapore’s leading contemporary creative talents, opened in New York City last Wednesday, September 23 in Madison Square Park. Coinciding with Singapore’s Golden Jubilee celebrations and on display through September 27, the showcase offers audiences the opportunity to gain a different perspective on Singapore through the lens of its emerging arts community.
 
Curated by award-winning Singaporean architect and artist Randy Chan, Singapore: Inside Out featured 18 new commissions created by 20 talents, and offered a glimpse into the creative movement that has taken root in Singapore across a spectrum of fields including architecture, design, fashion, film, food, music, and literary, performing and visual arts. Inside the lattice of scaffolding, visitors to Singapore: Inside Out interacted with the exhibits, experience live musical performances, engaging panel discussions , theatrical encounters, and much more.
 
The showcase was officially launched by His Excellency Ashok Mirpuri, Singapore Ambassador to the United States during a VIP event on September 24. Joining him are key members of the local creative, trade and media communities.
 
“Singapore and the United States share a close relationship across a range of strategic and long-standing initiatives, including our cultural links. In celebrating 50 years of this relationship since Singapore’s independence in 1965, we are pleased to highlight this cultural showcase in New York City, the global creative capital. Through Singapore: Inside Out, we hope to share a perspective of Singapore’s vibrant and contemporary arts scene, and look forward to spark new opportunities for creative exchanges. Singapore: Inside Out had considerable success in Beijing and London earlier this year, and I expect that it will receive a warm reception in New York City as well,” said Ambassador Mirpuri.
 
In addition to the works featured in the Singapore: Inside Out showcase, collaborations between American and Singaporean artists added local flavor to the five-day festival’s exciting line-up. These included panel discussions such as the artist sharing session moderated by a Guggenheim Foundation curator between Singaporean artist Robert Zhao and New York-based artist, writer, and curator Jason Wee, the U.S. launch of the literary anthology “Union” by Singaporean writer, Alvin Pang and U.S. writer, Ravi Shankar, as well as performances like “Syndicate Subsessions,” an audio-visual showcase, by Singaporean collective, Syndicate, featuring musicians Octover, NADA, DJ-duo Kiat and Cherry, and visual artist Brandon Tay, along with Los Angeles-based rapper Nocando.
 
“Following the success of No Country: Contemporary Art for South and Southeast Asia organised by Guggenheim UBS MAP Curator, June Yap, we’re thrilled to once again collaborate on a project that deepens the understanding of artistic practices in one of Asia’s creative hubs and brings awareness to Singapore’s creative community,” said, Joan Young, Director of Curatorial Affairs, Guggenheim Museum. “In the spirit of the Guggenheim UBS MAP Global Art Initiative, I look forward to an illuminating session of discussion on art and cross-cultural exchange with some of Singapore’s inspiring young talents.”
 
Following its run in New York, Singapore: Inside Out will return to Singapore for its homecoming from 27 November to 6 December.
 
Please refer to the Annex A for further information about the showcase and programme schedule.
 
Partner events throughout New York City also further shone the spotlight on Singapore’s talents:
 
New York-based Singaporeans contributed to events including “Something to Write Home About” (Sept. 12-22) , a 10-day art event showcasing short films, visual arts and theater Singapore Art at Bergdorf Goodman (Sept. 20-27), where famed New York-based Singaporean photographer, John Clang, had his work featured at the iconic store Literary programs Madison Square Reads (Sept. 24) and Reading Rangers (Sept. 25) featuring Singaporean writer Amanda Lee Koe and graphic novelist Colin Goh. The city was also treated to tastes of Singapore with events such as the Singapore Restaurant Week (Sept. 18-27) and a Singapore Hawker Pop Up featuring local street fare (Sept. 23-27) in partnership with The Daily Meal, Singapore Feast at Bergdorf Goodman (Sept. 20-27), and a special Singapore Onde Onde Shake from the Madison Square Park outpost of Shake Shack (Sept. 24-27). More Singaporean talents will be featured in events across the city at LAVO (Sept. 26), Queens Museum (Oct 3-31) and Fred Torres Gallery (Sept. 17-Oct.24).
